intro: Pimpinella calycina, commonly known as the narrow-leaved cowparsley, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and grassy areas. Pimpinella calycina is not typically cultivated for ornamental purposes but is of interest to botanists and ecologists due to its ecological role and historical use in traditional medicine.
